content.webTitle: Some Alabama counties refuse marriage licenses to gay couples despite ruling

fields.headline: Some Alabama counties refuse marriage licenses to gay couples despite ruling
fields.bodyText: Hundreds of same-sex couples married in Alabama on Monday, surrounded by rainbow flags and cheering supporters, as a disparate map of marriage equality emerged in the state in which dozens more were denied the right to marry by state judges who refused to obey a federal order to allow such weddings. Alabama is legally the 37th state to allow same-sex marriage, but couples like Robert Povilat and Milton Persinger spent the day frustrated outside a courthouse because a county judge refused to abide by the ruling. “We’ll stay until the office closes at the end of the day,” said Povilat, who arrived at the Mobile County marriage license department just before 7am on Monday. Mobile County judge Don Davis closed his office doors and windows for more than two hours on Monday, eventually opening for people seeking other services like deeds. Meanwhile, Povilat said he and about a dozen others were still waiting in line at 3pm local time because Davis, like a number of other judges across the state, refused to issue marriage licenses. “We’re residents of Mobile County. We are residents of Mobile City, and we feel that with the laws that are in effect, that we should have the right to this in our city and in our county,” said Povilat. US district court judge Callie Granade struck down the state’s ban on same-sex marriage in January, and although she put a hold on the decision, that expired on Monday, paving the way for marriages across the state. “We felt confident that today the law would be obeyed and they would issues licenses,” said Povilat. Also waiting to marry in Mobile were Cari Searcy and Kimberly McKeand, the plaintiffs responsible for filing the lawsuit that resulted in marriage equality ruling. They had not married as of Monday afternoon because of Davis’s decision to not give out marriage licenses. Their lawyers filed a federal contempt motion against Davis, but Granade turned it down. Just as people started to enter Alabama courthouses in the morning, the supreme court said it would not grant the state’s request to extend the hold on Granade’s decision. The justices decided 7-2 against the stay, certifying that the federal government permits same-sex marriages in the state. The state’s chief justice, Roy Moore, issued an 11th-hour order on Sunday night, ordering telling probate judges not to obey the ruling. “Effective immediately, no probate judge of the State of Alabama nor any agent or employee of any Alabama probate judge shall issue or recognize a marriage license that is inconsistent” with state law, Moore said in the order. Moore has been fighting Granade’s ruling for weeks. He has made a career out of opposing the federal government on religious grounds and in 2003 was removed from his post as Alabama chief justice because he refused to remove a granite Ten Commandments monument weighing more than 5,200lb from the state judicial building. He was re-elected to the same post in November 2012. Moore’s statements defy the supremacy clause of the US constitution, which gives federal rulings precedence over lower court rulings. But his comments also helped incite a judicial rebellion in the state, with some judges refusing to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, and others abandoning offering marriage services to all people. A similar tactic was also used by Alabama judges decades earlier, when the supreme court ruled in 1967 that bans on interracial marriage are unconstitutional. Alabama’s governor, Robert Bentley, said in a statement that he will not take action against probate judges who ignore the order – or those following it. “Probate judges have a unique responsibility in our state, and I support them,” Bentley said. “I will not take any action against probate judges, which would only serve to further complicate this issue.” He also said he was disappointed with the supreme court’s decision to not extend the stay pending its own ruling on the constitutionality of same-sex marriage bans, which is due by the end of June. If the court rules that these bans are unconstitutional, Alabama judges who still refuse to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples could have their hand forced by higher courts or risk being removed from their positions. Equality Alabama and ACLU of Alabama are operating a hotline for people who are refused marriage licenses. ACLU of Alabama’s executive director, Susan Watson, said the hotline had received more than 50 complaints from people in the state. The group hopes to collect enough information to take legal action against probate judges who act against the federal ruling. “They are putting themselves at risk and I think they need to take a long and hard look at what they’re doing,” said Watson, who attended the first marriage in Montgomery.
